claim: Quadrupeds are represented on Chinese calendar.

supporting.text: The Chinese zodiac includes the Year of the Dog, which is a quadruped, as part of its 12-year cycle.

attacks.text: The Chinese zodiac includes the Year of the Dog, which is a quadruped, as part of its 12-year cycle.
Not all animals in the Chinese zodiac are quadrupeds; the Dragon is a mythical creature and does not fit the quadruped classification.
The Dragon is often depicted with four legs in traditional Chinese art, which would classify it as a quadruped despite its mythical nature.
The Chinese zodiac also includes the Year of the Monkey, which is primarily bipedal, not quadrupedal.
Monkeys frequently use all four limbs for locomotion, especially in arboreal settings, making them functionally quadrupeds in many contexts.

supporting.text: The Chinese zodiac features the Year of the Ox, another quadruped, symbolizing diligence and strength.

attacks.text: The Chinese zodiac features the Year of the Ox, another quadruped, symbolizing diligence and strength.
The Chinese zodiac also includes the Year of the Dragon, which is not a quadruped but a mythical creature with varying depictions.
While the Dragon is mythical, its traditional artistic depictions in Chinese culture often show it with four legs, making it functionally a quadruped in representation.
The Chinese zodiac includes the Year of the Rooster, which is a biped and not a quadruped.

supporting.text: The Year of the Horse, a quadruped, is one of the animals in the Chinese zodiac, representing speed and perseverance.

attacks.text: The Year of the Horse, a quadruped, is one of the animals in the Chinese zodiac, representing speed and perseverance.
The Chinese zodiac only includes 12 animals, and not all quadrupeds are represented (e.g., cats or elephants are not part of the zodiac).
The claim specifies 'represented,' not 'exhaustively included,' so the presence of at least one quadruped (the Horse) satisfies the claim.
The zodiac primarily symbolizes cultural and mythological traits, not biological classification, so 'quadruped' is irrelevant to its representation.
The Horse is biologically a quadruped, so its inclusion inherently represents quadrupeds regardless of the zodiac's symbolic focus.

supporting.text: The Chinese zodiac includes the Year of the Goat, a quadruped, associated with peace and harmony.

attacks.text: The Chinese zodiac includes the Year of the Goat, a quadruped, associated with peace and harmony.
The Chinese zodiac also includes the Year of the Dragon, which is not a quadruped, thus not all zodiac animals are quadrupeds.
While the Dragon is not a quadruped, the majority of Chinese zodiac animals (e.g., Ox, Horse, Pig) are quadrupeds, supporting the claim's general validity.
The Chinese zodiac's representation is symbolic, not biological, so classifying animals as quadrupeds is irrelevant to their zodiac significance.
Even if symbolic, the physical traits (like being quadrupedal) are part of the cultural imagery, making the classification meaningful.

supporting.text: The Year of the Pig, a quadruped, is part of the Chinese zodiac cycle, symbolizing wealth and honesty.

attacks.text: The Year of the Pig, a quadruped, is part of the Chinese zodiac cycle, symbolizing wealth and honesty.
Not all quadrupeds are represented in the Chinese zodiac; only 12 animals are included, leaving out many others.
The Chinese zodiac is a cultural representation, not an exhaustive biological classification, so it doesn't need to include all quadrupeds.
The claim implies broader representation of quadrupeds, but the zodiac focuses on symbolic meaning rather than taxonomic representation.
The zodiac's purpose is symbolic and cyclical, not to catalog animals, so the presence of one quadruped is sufficient for representation.

supporting.text: The Chinese zodiac's Year of the Tiger, a quadruped, represents bravery and competitiveness.

attacks.text: The Chinese zodiac's Year of the Tiger, a quadruped, represents bravery and competitiveness.
Not all quadrupeds are represented in the Chinese zodiac; only 12 animals are included, leaving out many others.
The 12 animals in the Chinese zodiac were selected for cultural and symbolic reasons, not just for being quadrupeds.
The Chinese zodiac primarily focuses on symbolic traits rather than biological classification, so quadrupedalism is not the main criterion.
The inclusion of the Tiger, a quadruped, still supports the claim that quadrupeds are represented, even if not all are included.
